postsData.name:
G. Brent Barkin
G. Brent Barkin
postsData.content:
Ok, I typically know better than to wade into politics. Hopefully this post isn't seen in that vein.

Saw the headline on this article whereandwarn of the impact of NIH cuts to indirect costs for research institutions.

One thing I was taught in economics is the fungibility of funds. This effectively means that, despite separation of budgets, money an organization gets for one purpose ultimately allows that organization to perform other unrelated purposes. If you give an institution money for one purpose, say $700M, it allows that organization to spend that much money elsewhere. It doesn't always hold to exact numbers, of course.

In this instance, while it is true that if the NIH chooses not to offset $700M of Harvard's costs, Harvard may very well make significant cuts in those research programs. Or...

There could be a recognition that part of the reason that Harvard has the $53,000,000,000 - that's right, $53 Billion with a B - endowment is because it has a phenomenal reputation as a research institution.

I certainly won't make friends at many schools by suggesting this, but for America to pay for soft costs of your academic research while your endowment amasses staggering wealth deserves to be evaluated. It is right for people to question it.

I'm bracing for the pushback here...
postsData.commentAdded: Thought-provoking perspective! The intersection of funding and research efficiency is crucial—how do we balance institutional wealth with public investment?

postsData.content:
Want to Say "No" to Your Boss? Here’s How to Do It Safely:

You don’t have to do everything. Use these pro-level responses instead:

___ Save this for later ___

1. Nearing Burnout:

“I want to contribute, but my workload is at capacity. Can we revisit this later?”

This shows commitment while protecting your performance and well-being.

2. Plate Is Full:

“I’m at max capacity right now. Which task should take priority to meet expectations?”

You’re not rejecting work—you’re asking for guidance, proving you’re solution-focused.

3. Need Backup:

“To meet the standard we need, I’ll need extra help. Can we bring in support?”

Frames help as necessary for quality, making it easier for your manager to approve.

4. Feeling Overloaded:

“I’m concerned adding more will hurt my other projects. Can we shift the deadline?”

Focuses on maintaining high standards, not just checking off tasks.

5. Other Deadlines:

“I’m wrapping up another priority now. Once that’s done, I can give this my focus.”

Reassures your boss the task will get done—without overloading yourself.

6. Work-Life Balance:

“I have a personal commitment tonight. Can I start this first thing tomorrow morning?”

Maintains boundaries while showing reliability and professionalism.

7. Need More Clarity:

“I want to stay aligned with expectations. Can you clarify which task takes priority?”

Ensures you’re working on what actually matters.

8. Smarter Approach:

“What if we tried [alternative solution] to get the same result more effectively?”

Positions you as a problem-solver, not just someone avoiding extra work.

9. Outside Your Role:

“This isn’t part of my scope, but I’m happy to assist where my skills fit best.”

Sets clear boundaries while still being helpful.

Saying “yes” to everything leads to burnout. Saying “no” the right way builds respect.

Which one do you need to use ASAP?

postsData.content:
𝗢𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗮 𝘀𝗶𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽.
Here’s how to fix it.

Leaders don’t struggle because they lack vision or effort.
They struggle because complexity slows them down.

Too many steps. Too many details. Too many decisions.

When communication is unclear, teams hesitate.
When processes are convoluted, execution stalls.
When leaders overcomplicate, progress stops.

The solution is 𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻.

𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘀𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗞𝗜𝗦𝗦 𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗲 (𝗞𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝗜𝘁 𝗦𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁 & 𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲) 𝘁𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽:

1️⃣ Cut Through the Noise
Lengthy explanations create confusion.
Keep communication precise, direct, and outcome-driven.

2️⃣ Simplify Decision-Making
Excessive options lead to hesitation.
Eliminate distractions and focus on what truly matters.

3️⃣ Prioritize Clarity Over Length
A well-structured, concise message carries more weight than a long, unfocused one.
Every word should serve a purpose.

4️⃣ Make Simplicity a Leadership Standard
Before implementing a strategy or process,
ask: Is there a simpler way to achieve the same result?

5️⃣ Streamline Team Communication
Unclear direction leads to inefficiency.
Ensure every message is actionable and unambiguous.

6️⃣ Remove Unnecessary Complexity
Bureaucracy slows progress.
Reduce redundant approvals, streamline workflows, and empower teams to act.

7️⃣ Lead with Impact, Not Complexity
Leadership is not about making things sound sophisticated.
It is about driving results through clarity and focus.

Simplicity is not a shortcut.
It is a strategy.

When leaders prioritize clarity, organizations move faster, teams perform better, and results improve.

Where do you see complexity slowing down your leadership?
Let’s discuss.

If this resonated with you, share it with your network. ️

A PEO.

A PEO (Professional Employer Organization) is like having an HR department, compliance wizard, and payroll ninja all in one—but without the office coffee breath or passive-aggressive sticky notes.

️ Offering their team benefits so good, their employees cry tears of joy.

And you?

You’re out here trying to do it all yourself, probably eating cold pizza at your desk and wondering if burnout counts as cardio.

Remember your first day at the gym?

I do.

I was a skinny twig - 120lbs as a senior in high school.
I walked into Planet Fitness - intimidated, nervous, and self-conscious.

Unsure where to even start.

I saw guys lifting heavy weights, moving with confidence, knowing exactly what to do.

And then there was me...
Aeropostale t-shirt, sweatband on the left arm, and a gnarly phone belt clip...

I rocked the hell out of that though! 

But it didn't take away the fact that I felt lost, out of place, and comparing myself to everyone around me.

Can you relate?

Let me tell you - those feelings are NORMAL. They’re VALID.

Starting something new - especially something you're not confident in - is never easy.

But here’s the truth: Every single person in that gym started exactly where you are right now.

Square 1. Day 1.

Even the fittest, strongest, most experienced people in that gym? They’ve all been in your shoes.

And guess what? They’re not judging you. In fact, most of them would be happy to help.

The key? Stick with it. Stay consistent.

You'll have days where you crush it.
You'll have days where you don’t even want to show up.
You'll have days where every excuse tells you to stay home.

Go anyway.

Because every rep, every set, every step forward…
You’re proving to yourself that you can do hard things.

You’re building discipline.
You’re sharpening your mindset.
You’re creating the future version of yourself that you’ll be proud of.

And one day?
You’ll be the one inspiring the newcomer.

Just don't forget the Aeropostale t-shirt, the sweatband, and the phone belt clip! Nothing screams "approachable" like these accessories.

Franchise Myths Busted! 

Thinking of joining a franchise but heard some scary stories? Don't let myths hold you back! 

 Myth #1: "I won't have any control over my business." 
 Truth: Franchises offer a proven system, but you still have plenty of freedom to make your own decisions and build your business.

 Myth #2: "Franchises are too expensive." 
 Truth: While there are costs involved, franchises often have financing options and a higher success rate, leading to a better return on investment. 

 Myth #3: "All franchises are the same." 
 Truth: There's a huge variety of franchises out there! Find one that aligns with your passions and goals. 

Don't let misconceptions stop you from exploring the world of franchising! Reach out to learn more.

postsData.content:
Optical Data Transfer using Light! 

Ever wondered how data can be transmitted wirelessly using just light? Well, me and my friend took on this challenge and built this simple yet effective Optical data transfer project using ESP8266 (NodeMCU) modules, a laser, and a photodiode.

How does it work?

We convert a string message into binary and transmit it using the laser. The key idea is that each LASER blink represents 1 while its off-state represents 0. Using this technique, we send the entire binary message through light. The photodiode detects these signals, sends them to the receiving ESP8266, and reconstructs the original message.

Check out the full demonstration in my YouTube video: 


Huge thanks tofor being my co-creator on this project! This was truly a team effort!

postsData.content:
97.8% of the value of innovations goes to imitators (Harvard Business Review). In business, the key isn’t always being first-it’s being best.

"I scroll through my feed..."
"Moment."
"I’ve seen this post before."
"This one too."
"And that one looks exactly like the one I read last week."

I can feel the frustration building as everything seems like a copy of a copy, but then I remember:

 The iPhone wasn’t the first smartphone, but Apple’s version revolutionized the market.

 “I Will Always Love You” was originally written by Dolly Parton, but Whitney Houston made it a global anthem.

 Uber didn’t invent taxis, but they perfected and popularized the concept.

 Netflix adapted Blockbuster's model but innovated with streaming.

How many times have you hesitated to act because you thought your idea wasn’t original enough?

According to Oded Shenkar in Harvard Business Review, nearly 98% of the value from innovations is captured not by the original innovators, but by those who refine, scale, and commercialize what’s already been done.

This is called IMOVATION - the art of blending imitation with innovation to create something extraordinary.

The takeaway? Progress isn’t about creating something entirely new; it’s about improving what’s already been done.

𝗪𝗵𝘆 𝗰𝗼𝗽𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀:

 Proven success: Build on ideas that have already worked.

 Faster learning: Learn from others' wins and mistakes.

 Incremental improvement: Tweak what’s already there to make it better.

 Authenticity: Solve real problems by adapting solutions that already exist.

 Expanded creativity: Combine existing ideas in new ways to spark innovation.

Good copying isn’t plagiarism-it’s responsible adaptation with your unique twist. It’s standing on the shoulders of giants while adding your own perspective.

Do you believe originality still reigns supreme? Let’s discuss.

And followfor more insights.

postsData.content:
Had a meeting with a $12M company last week. 

The CEO was proud they'd reduced their client concentration risk.

They used to have one customer at 80% of revenue.
Now they have four customers making up 70%.

Progress? Maybe.

Let’s dig deeper…

1. They don't have real differentiation in their market
2. They struggle to articulate their unique value
3. They look exactly like their competitors
4. Their growth is coming from expanding existing accounts, not winning new ones

When I told them I probably couldn't help, they were surprised.

"But don't you fix sales problems?"

Here's the truth: Before you worry about your sales process, pipeline or hiring more reps (or even me).

You need to answer one fundamental question:

→ Can prospects tell you apart from your competitors?

If not, that's your real problem.

Your sales team can't sell what they can't differentiate.

And customers won't pay a premium for what looks like a commodity.

Sometimes the hardest thing is telling someone you're not their problem even when they're ready to pay you to fix it.

postsData.content:
DOUBT is the hurdle to get over NOT failure! The path to success is paved with FAILURE. Our fear of failure and doubting our abilities is holding us back.

How many times have you talked yourself out of pursuing something because you doubted your abilities? Maybe it was applying for that dream job, starting a side hustle, or sharing your ideas with the world.

Here’s the truth: Failure is a teacher. It’s a stepping stone to growth, resilience, and success. But doubt? Doubt is a dream killer. It’s the voice in your head that says, “You’re not good enough,” “What if you fail?” or “It’s not the right time.”

The reality is, you’ll never know what you’re capable of until you try. Every successful person you admire has faced failure—but they didn’t let doubt stop them.

 Here’s how to silence doubt and chase your dreams:
1️⃣ Acknowledge It: Recognize when doubt is holding you back.
2️⃣ Reframe Your Mindset: Replace “What if I fail?” with “What if I succeed?”
3️⃣ Take Small Steps: Progress builds confidence. Start with one actionable step today.
4️⃣ Surround Yourself with Support: Find people who believe in you, even when you don’t.

Remember, failure is temporary, but regret lasts forever. Don’t let doubt rob you of the chance to achieve something extraordinary.

 What’s one dream you’ve been doubting? Let’s encourage each other in the comments. 

Repost ️ if you find it useful. Follow me,andfor more leadership insights like these!

Lead differently! Beat yesterday! Be better humans.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Doubt can be paralyzing, but embracing failure as a learning tool is key to growth. Lets conquer our dreams together! 🌟🚀

postsData.content:
The Greatest Leadership Challenge Isn't Uncertainty - It's How We Face It

Most leaders don't fail because of uncertainty itself.

They get caught in reactive patterns that feel safe but limit growth:

• Analyzing endlessly instead of taking purposeful action
• Waiting for perfect clarity that never arrives
• Trying to control what can't be controlled
• Defending against change instead of shaping it

But here's what changes everything:

Uncertainty isn't your enemy. It's your opening to greater possibility.

The most effective leaders haven't eliminated fear - they've learned to work with uncertainty as a creative force. They:

 Listen Before Deciding: They tune into emerging patterns and weak signals that others miss. This isn't just data analysis - it's developing a sense of what's possible.

 Embrace Complexity: Instead of fighting against uncertainty, they use it as a canvas for innovation. They know perfect control is an illusion.

 Lead Through Questions: They build teams that thrive on collective intelligence, knowing that the best insights often come from collaborative exploration.

The future opens to those who learn to move with uncertainty.

Your next breakthrough isn't waiting for perfect conditions.
It's waiting for you to step forward into the unknown.

Let's face it.

What opportunity is uncertainty offering you right now?

Joelle Thayer

postsData.content:
Picture this: 3 AM. I'm at the kitchen counter, staring at a page of meticulously researched solutions to my mom’s challenges. I know these ideas could help. I know they’d work.

And in just a few hours, I'll sit across from her, share everything I’ve prepared…and she’ll shut down every single one.

That's when it hit me – being right isn't enough. In fact, sometimes, it's actually the problem.

Because let's be real: None of us likes being told what to do, even when we desperately need the advice. (Myself included. Especially myself.)

So then, what does work? How do we help people not just see their challenges, but own them — and discover solutions they'll actually embrace?

Turns out, my father had been telling me the answer all along, I just didn’t really get it:

Stop solving. Start asking.

Instead of offering solutions, try:
- "What do you think is getting in the way?"
- "How would you like things to be different?"
- "What's worked for you in the past?"

The real magic unfolds when you:
- Get genuinely curious about their world
- Share observations without judgment ("I notice you get excited when...")
- Create space for them to connect their own dots

That morning, I sat with my mom at her kitchen table. As I fought every urge to pull out my carefully crafted solutions, I asked instead, "What would make things easier for you?"

She paused, stirred her coffee, and started talking. Not defending. Not resisting. Just...sharing. And in that moment, I saw what my father had been trying to teach me for years.

The hardest part wasn't letting go of my solutions. It was realizing that watching someone find their own way is both terrifying and beautiful.

But when my mother came up with her own plan that morning, her eyes had a spark I hadn't seen in years.

Sometimes the best way to help isn't by being right. It's by being quiet long enough to let someone else find their way.

What's your go-to question when someone -- an employee, spouse, child or colleague -- comes to you with a problem?

postsData.content:
After just 18 months in a corporate job, I found myself questioning everything.

I had two choices:
→ Join a startup.
→ Bet on myself and build something from scratch.

And honestly?
Starting my own thing felt less terrifying.

Sounds crazy, right?

But here’s what no one tells you—
The hardest part of leaving corporate isn’t leaving.

It’s what happens next.

Because once you take that chance, reality hits:
→ No guaranteed income. You don’t just “get paid” anymore—you have to create your own paycheck.

→ No clear direction. Every decision is yours to make, and most of the time, you have no clue what you’re doing.

→ No safety net. No HR, no manager, no company perks—just you, figuring things out as you go.

The one thing that kept me from sinking?
Consistent skill-building.

For two solid years, I didn’t just work—I sharpened my skills.
I treated learning like a job.
Every. Single. Day.

And honestly?
I’m still learning. (Spoiler: That never stops.)

Was freelancing easier? Absolutely not.
If anything, it was tougher than corporate.

But it gave me something corporate never could:
Ownership of my path.

And that?
That made all the difference.

postsData.content:
The 11 hardest career lessons
that secretly create the most successful leaders

Let’s be honest,
↳ No one prepares you the setbacks that make you question yourself.
↳ The challenges that feel unfair, exhausting, and impossible to navigate.

But here’s the truth.
Those very challenges hold the blueprint for growth.

The best leaders don’t avoid challenges.
They decode them.

Now, it’s your turn. Here’s how: ⬇️

1. When you're underpaid
↳ Waiting for recognition won’t get you a raise.
↳ Track your impact and tie it to business results.
↳ Negotiate from strength, not need.

2. When office politics drain you
↳ Influence beats involvement in drama.
↳ Build key relationships before you need them.
↳ Keep the focus on your results, not the noise.

3. When your boss is difficult
↳ Align with their language - mirror key phrases they value.
↳ Acknowledge their concerns before responding.
↳ Stay neutral, not emotional.

4. When workload overwhelms
↳ Don’t just work harder - realign priorities.
↳ Break tasks into 25-minute sprints to regain control.
↳ Master the strategic ‘no’.

5. When growth feels blocked
↳ No one will hand you a roadmap - create your own.
↳ Seek mentors outside your direct circle.
↳ Treat every project as a learning opportunity.

6. When feedback is vague
↳ Guessing leads to frustration - ask for specifics.
↳ “Can you share an example of what good looks like?”
↳ Align expectations early to avoid confusion.

7. When coworkers test your patience
↳ Set boundaries, not battles.
↳ Address actions, not personalities.
↳ Their behavior reflects on them - not you.

8. When meetings waste your time
↳ Long calls don’t mean productivity.
↳ Propose focused 25-minute alternatives.
↳ Ask: “Could this be an email?”

9. When others take credit for your work
↳ Your silence lets it happen.
↳ “I appreciate the mention - here’s how I developed this.”
↳ Keep records and involve key decision-makers early.

10. When culture turns toxic
↳ Align with influence, not dysfunction.
↳ Observe who really drives decisions and build alliances.
↳ Exit strategically - on your terms.

postsData.name:
Ned Arick
Ned Arick
postsData.content:
The best career advice I ever got was that the work you do today will bear fruit in 90 days.

No sooner.

At first, I didn’t get it.

I was trying to change my life overnight, reading all the self-help books, designing the “perfect” morning routine, and setting massive goals.

It worked… for a week.

Then I missed a day.

And another.

Before I knew it, I was off track entirely.

Sound familiar?

Here’s why most habits fail:

1️⃣ You Start Too Big:

You get inspired and try to overhaul your whole life at once! Workout routines, journaling, meditation, meal prep, productivity hacks.

It’s overwhelming, and when you miss a day, it’s game over.

Instead: Shrink it. Start with a habit so small it’s impossible to fail.

Think: Write 1 sentence, not a full journal entry. Just go to the gym to get a quick pump, not a full workout.

Small wins build momentum.

2️⃣ You Copy Someone Else’s Routine:

You read about someone’s 5am cold showers, 10 step morning routine, and perfect productivity system, and think, “I’ll do that!”

But it’s their life, not yours.

Habits stick when they fit into your day. Instead of forcing change, anchor new habits to things you already do

After brushing your teeth, do 10 pushups.

After making your coffee, open up your Bible.

This approach works because you’re building on your life, not trying to rebuild it.

3️⃣ You Rely on Motivation:

Motivation is fleeting.

Netflix, TikTok, and doom scrolling will win every time if you’re relying on willpower.

What works instead?

Systems.

Tiny, anchored, celebrated habits that remove decision fatigue and make consistency automatic.

 Here’s the secret:

The habits you stick with today will shape your future self.

But you don’t need to be perfect, you just need to start small, stay consistent, and make it yours.

 Remember this:

The work you do today will bear fruit in 90 days. What kind of life are you planting for yourself?

 What’s one small habit you’re building this week?

If you're unsure...

Go check out this week's Meaningful Momentum Newsletter.

I discuss exactly how to get out of habit hopping and into a new routine that takes you from where you are to where you were meant to be.

Check it out:

comments.commentText: In my experience what rally works is being accountable and change one habit at a time. My accountability comes down to reporting my assistant (who's also in charge of organizing my calendar), what are the things I do during the day. I found that focusing on only one habit at a time makes all the difference. A few months ago it was social media. Today is how early I get up. In order to change that, I report her what time I went to sleep and why. I already managed going getting to sleep one hour sooner (and do it on autopilot). This took me more than a month though, but it's well worth it.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! 🌱 Embracing small habits truly paves the way for lasting change. Excited to start planting my seeds this week! 🚀

Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Science & Robotics
Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Science & Robotics
postsData.content:
How does a PC communicate with a microcontroller that lacks a native USB port?

It’s all thanks to the USB/UART bridge – a powerful tool in embedded systems.

Whether you’re working on debugging, IoT, or industrial applications, understanding this bridge can simplify hardware integration and boost communication reliability. Here’s a clear breakdown of how USB/UART bridges streamline these connections and some real-world use cases:

 Data Flow & Conversion: The bridge handles data flow from USB to UART, transforming complex USB signals into a format compatible with microcontrollers.

 Reliable Debugging: By linking to a terminal, the bridge makes it easy to capture live data logs, trace issues, and get real-time insights – essential for identifying bugs quickly.

 IoT Communication: For IoT applications, USB/UART bridges enable seamless data exchange between sensors and microcontrollers, especially in prototyping and testing phases.

 Industrial Monitoring: In industrial environments, where legacy devices still use UART, these bridges connect them to modern systems, making data collection and monitoring far more efficient.

Bridges like FTDI, CP210x, and CH340 have specific strengths, from speed and reliability to cost-effectiveness. Each bridge plays a unique role, so knowing when to use which bridge can be a game-changer.

Dive into my latest article on parlezVousTechto explore step-by-step details, common pitfalls, and best practices.

comments.commentText: Mitigation?

Shravan Singh R. Cutting a track is an extreme and impractical solution in production. The real question is: how do we secure access while keeping devices maintainable?
- Disable UART in firmware and enable it only for development.
- Use authentication to restrict access.
- Apply hardware protections like fuses or epoxy.
Security is about balance, not just blocking everything
For industrial use cases, using a higher-quality bridge like FTDI can be worth the investment due to its reliability. Anyone have experience with different bridge options?

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! The USB/UART bridge truly enhances microcontroller communication. Excited to read your article for more tips on effective integration!

postsData.name:
Amos Bar-Joseph

postsData.content:
Zero to $4M ARR, in 12 months, with 6 employees. This B2B startup scaled lean by breaking the first rule of startups:

They didn't start by building an MVP.

After founding two startups, raising multiple rounds, and landing two acquisitions, I've seen firsthand how the game has changed.

Yet 15 years after Eric Ries' "The Lean Startup," founders are still running the same playbook:

1. Build MVP
2. Run countless sales experiments
3. Scale marketing

But in 2025, that playbook is burning founders out:

24-36 months to find product-market fit
$10M-$30M in funding gone
Bloated teams brute-forcing growth

And here’s the truth nobody tells you: In a world where AI can build anything overnight, the battle isn’t over features. It’s over attention.

The new playbook? Flip the script upside down:
Build Audience → Test Demand → Ship Product

It's called Audience-Led Growth (h/t&who pioneered this thinking).

And at, we're not just preaching it - we're betting our company on it.

Our goal? $30M ARR with just the 3 founders. The secret isn't JUST human + AI scalability - it's building an audience that's hungry for what we'll create.

Think about it:

When AI can build any feature overnight
When every startup has access to the same tools
When products are becoming commodities

The winners won't be the ones with the best AI. They'll be the ones with the strongest audience.

Need proof? Let's talk about's RB2B.

Before writing a single line of code, they cracked something more valuable than product-market fit:

They cracked exponential audience growth.

The result? $4M ARR in 12 months with just 6 people.

How?

They flipped the traditional playbook:

1. Built massive reach in their target market
2. Tested offerings with their engaged audience
3. Developed only what already had proven demand

That's Audience-led growth. And it's about to change everything about how we build startups.

The next wave of billion-dollar companies won’t be the ones with the biggest funding rounds or feature-packed products.

They’ll be small, elite teams who master AI scalability and Audience-Market Fit.

And they won't just compete with giants.

They'll become them.

𝐒𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬, 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐚𝐩𝐞 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐬 𝐨𝐟𝐟! 

As leaders, we all find ourselves veering off track at times. I’ve been there—it’s not fun.

But I’ve learned these moments are an invitation to 𝐠𝐞𝐭 𝐜𝐮𝐫𝐢𝐨𝐮𝐬:

• What’s happening that’s affecting me now?
• Why do I feel disconnected or out of sorts?
• Am I carrying this alone when I don’t have to?

When things get tough, often the “𝒔𝒉𝒐𝒖𝒍𝒅𝒔” creep in:

“I should know how to do this.”
“I should be able to handle it all.”

Truth is, 𝐬𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐚𝐩𝐞 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐬 𝐨𝐟𝐟—𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭’𝐬 𝐚 𝐬𝐢𝐠𝐧. It means we need support. Your mentor, coach, network, or PBD (personal board of directors) matter most in these moments.

Don’t wait until you’re struggling to lean on them.

𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐚𝐩𝐞 𝐬𝐥𝐢𝐩𝐬, 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐜𝐡 𝐨𝐮𝐭. 𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐝𝐨𝐧’𝐭 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐨 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐧𝐞!

I’m grateful for those who have lifted me.

Who lifts you?

I THOUGHT TECH WAS THE HARD PART.

 TURNS OUT, IT WAS THE PEOPLE.

A few years ago, I rolled out a cutting-edge data governance framework, convinced it would revolutionize the way our team worked.

The tech was solid, the strategy was airtight…
But the resistance? BRUTAL.

The pushback wasn’t about the tool; it was about fear, uncertainty, and loss of control.

And I learned the hard way:
 Change isn’t just about systems, it’s about psychology.

 Up to 70% of transformations fail because leaders focus on the tech and forget about the people.

But what if we flipped the script? What if, instead of forcing change, we created buy-in from within?

In my latest article, I break down:
 Why resistance happens (and how to turn it around)
 The leadership mindset shift that changes everything
 Proven frameworks (Kotter, ADKAR) that actually work
 Real-world case studies of companies that got it right

 Read it below.

Have you ever introduced a change that didn’t land as expected? How did your team react?
Let’s talk in the comments! ⬇

postsData.name:
Jean Larkin
Jean Larkin
postsData.content:
Remember when leadership was all about the leader and the leader only?

The woman making the decisions, always with the answers.
The man at the helm, commanding attention and taking control.
The person steering the ship, dictating the course and calling all the shots.

Think about the larger than life personas we grew up watching:
⇢ Gibbs from NCIS—decisive, confident, and always in control (or quick with a head slap)
⇢ Miranda Priestly from The Devil Wears Prada—a commanding and sometimes cruel presence who made sure everyone knew who was boss.
⇢ House—where to start… addiction or unwavering arrogance.

Back then, leadership was defined by being the loudest and most authoritative voice in the room.

But today, what employees value in leadership couldn’t be more different.

Take leaders like Ted Lasso or the new Miranda Bailey addressing burnout in young residents. Although sometimes unconventional or even silly, these are the leaders people admire now—leaders who empower their teams, inspire collaboration, and focus on bringing out the best in others.

When you look at what employees appreciate most in their leaders—whether through Glassdoor reviews or everyday conversations—it’s not about a larger than life boss or a creative genius.

It’s about how leaders empower others, create space for collaboration, and bring out the best in their teams.

This shift didn’t just happen for me professionally—it’s been personal, too.

One of my greatest strengths is how fast my brain works.

But I’ve learned that this strength also has a downside: I used to jump to solutions so quickly that I didn’t take the time to fully listen to my team or understand what they truly needed.

So, I had to shift.

Now, I pause. I take a breath. I leave space for others to finish their thoughts. And I ask clarifying questions like:

“How can I best support you?
“What do you need right now?"
"Do you need a shoulder, a solution, or a cheerleader?”

This shift—from jumping to answers to creating space for others—has been transformational.

Leadership isn’t about how I show up; it’s about how I help others show up as their best selves.

The best leaders don’t seek attention, titles, or the spotlight—they focus on elevating others and creating impact through their team.

How has your perspective on leadership evolved? Let’s share ideas in the comments.

comments.commentText:
I’ve come to believe that the best leaders are the ones who encourage you not to follow them, but to make your own way. They show you what’s possible and give you the freedom to sink or swim. Yes, they may help clear the way, but ultimately it’s up to you to - sometimes a team - to figure it out.

This is scary to many. But for those who can self-manage and adopt more of an entrepreneurial mindset it can ultimately move them to actually leave and do their own thing.

Jean Larkin - Thank you for sparking such an important discussion! Over the years, my approach to leadership has shifted significantly. Early on, I focused heavily on strategy, structure, and outcomes—ensuring that processes were followed and goals were met. While those are still important, my leadership style has evolved to prioritize people and relationships above all else.

I’ve come to see leadership as less about directing and more about empowering. Actively listening, fostering trust, and creating space for collaboration have become central to my approach. I’ve also learned that vulnerability and authenticity are not signs of weakness but powerful tools to connect with and inspire teams.

Thanks for sharing your mindset shift about leadership, Melissa. I wholeheartedly agree.

And still, all too often leadership training (if any) is focused on the strategy, structure, and outcomes. Rather than the human attributes to empower and bring out the best in the people around you -- which truly makes all of the difference.

When we take care of our people they take care of everything else!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Evolving leadership styles emphasize empowerment and collaboration—truly the key to fostering strong teams! 🌟

Recently, I met an old friend. While discussing on various topics, 

Our conversation naturally circled back to one of all our favorite topic: coding, code reviews, and the journey to becoming a better developer.

This discussion inspired me to write this post. I put together a quick cheatsheet as well

Great developers are more than code-producing machines. Coding is about more than just writing code; it’s about developing diverse skills.

We discussed how true excellence in development means balancing technical prowess with critical thinking, collaboration, and a continuous drive to learn.

Every aspect of our work, from rigorous code reviews to insightful design discussions, fosters professional and problem-solving advancement.

During our chat, we highlighted several key areas that set exceptional developers apart:

𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁𝗳𝘂𝗹 𝗖𝗼𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗙𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗯𝗮𝗰𝗸, 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝘂𝗼𝘂𝘀 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗖𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗼𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗺𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀

Below are some of the areas where coding and code reviews needs to focus:

 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗥𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀

• Meets the functional requirements

 𝗖𝗼𝗱𝗲 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲

• Variable Name & Descriptive (spell, short names )

• Coding Style

• Scoping

• Code Duplication

• Long Function / Classes

• Comments

• Error checking & Handling

• Documentation

• No Magic numbers

• Logging

• Input Validation

• Error Codes

• Return Types


 𝗧𝗲𝘀𝘁𝘀, 𝗩𝗮𝗹𝗶𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 & 𝗧𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴

• Security (Vulnerabilities), Input sanitization

• Performance (Time & Space Complexity) (CPU, Memory, Disk)

• Right Data Structures

• Memory Management, Leaks & Vulnerabilities

• Unit, functional, Integration Testing

• Positive, negative, boundary, edge, mutation testing

• Find Defects

• Test Coverage

• Benchmarking

• Comparison with Other Implementations

• Efficiency, Scalability

• Concurrency, Race Condition, Dead Locks

• Doesn’t break existing functionality

 𝗖𝗼𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗕𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗽𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘀𝗲𝘀

• Solid Code Principles

• Design Patterns

• Coupling

• Correctness

• Simplicity

• Complexity

• Using Language Features

• Code modularity, Reusability

• Maintainability

• Readability

• Documentation

• Portability

• Compatibility

• Extensibility


 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗴𝘁𝗵 & 𝗪𝗲𝗮𝗸𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗱𝗲

postsData.content:
For four years, I said, "I'm not ready."

I wanted to freelance.

I kept learning and planning.
I was in motion, not in action.

2018 to 2022?
I stayed stuck, always preparing.

In 2022, I began freelancing.
And I'm doing.

I did the planning mistake again.

For two years, I planned YouTube.

I studied content strategies.
I watched endless tutorials.
I said, "I'll do it later."


In November 2024, I learned:
The right time never comes.
↳ I started messy.
↳ No clear plan.
↳ No perfect setup.

→ Just action.
And I'm proud of that action.

Here’s what I learned:

1: Motion seems productive, yet it's only prep.

2: Action feels tough, but it works.

3: You never feel fully ready.
So, start before you are ready.

4: Progress comes from doing and learning.

5: The best way to improve? Act now.


You don't need a perfect plan.
You just need to start.


P.S. Are you in motion or action? (Motion/Action)

postsData.content:
Why Sales Training Alone Isn’t Enough—Salespeople Must Master Negotiation to Win 

I’ve spent years in sales, coaching, and negotiation training, working across industries, from high-stakes corporate sales to complex deal-making. And one thing is crystal clear:

 Selling alone doesn’t close deals. Negotiation does.
Even if you’re a master of consultative selling, there comes a moment where selling stops working—and negotiation must take over.

Too many salespeople step into the business battlefield armed only with selling techniques—pitching, persuading, handling objections—but with no defense, no counterattack, no ability to adjust. Selling alone is like fighting with one hand tied behind your back.

 The Biggest Sales Challenges—And Why Negotiation is the Answer

1. Getting Ghosted by Prospects
 Selling alone: You chase, follow up, and hope for a response.
 With negotiation: You create urgency and leverage so prospects feel compelled to engage.
 Negotiation skill: Position your offer as a loss if ignored, rather than just another sales pitch.

2. Customers Expect More & Give Less
 Selling alone: You pile on more benefits, hoping to outshine competitors.
 With negotiation: You shift the conversation to value, not price, making customers work for concessions too.
 Negotiation skill: Trade, don’t cave—if they want a lower price, they commit to a longer contract.

3. Intense Market Competition
 Selling alone: You get stuck in price wars.
 With negotiation: You differentiate beyond price—leveraging relationships, exclusivity, and structured deals.
 Negotiation skill: Control the deal structure so competitors can’t easily match your terms.

4. Pricing Objections Kill Deals
 Selling alone: You offer discounts just to close.
 With negotiation: You justify value through ROI, risk reduction, and strategic concessions—without cutting margins.
 Negotiation skill: Shift the conversation from cost to investment.

5. Long Sales Cycles Drain Energy
 Selling alone: You wait, follow up, and hope for a decision.
 With negotiation: You control the timeline with decision triggers and strategic urgency.
 Negotiation skill: Create real deadlines that move deals forward.

Know When to Stop Selling & Start Negotiating

Even consultative selling has limits. At some point:
You’ve pitched. You’ve positioned value. You’ve listened.
But if you keep selling when you should be negotiating, you lose control.
 Selling presents value.
 Negotiation shapes the terms of that value.
 Sales gets you in the door. Negotiation gets you the contract.

The best salespeople aren’t just sellers—they are deal architects.

Are your teams negotiating, or just selling? Because the real winners in today’s market aren’t just the best salespeople…
They are the best negotiators.

I’m often told that I don’t look sick 

And most of the time I would agree that looks don’t tell the whole story

Cancer has ebs and flows -

Really good days - even great times

Then there’s the side effects that beat you down and hope hides from you

But for me, there’s joy in all of it because I have made it one more day, week, year,

More than expected.

And that’s my win -  no matter how I feel today, I can say to myself I have made it one more day- especially when it’s hard

For those I meet- being sorry that I have cancer is the “awkward polite” comment

However, a better option for me, is to celebrate  our crossing paths at this time

We may never meet again- so why not celebrate  our brief conversation or laugh at whatever brings us together?

I hope we can all start to celebrate  no matter what brings us together - not just cancer or illnesses-

And we care about each other’s health and wellbeing too

Checking for cancer should be our daily routine and not just a boring  annoyance that pops up in our social media feeds

I have terminal lung cancer- unless you have X-ray vision or some supernatural gift…

I doubt you can tell that I’m that ill.

Cancer is not always visible to anyone else, but those who are close to it, it’s something that can cloud ️ your vision for hope, laughter, joy, and life experiences

And that’s just not what I want in my life or anyone else’s experience

Don’t assume anything about people who tell you they have cancer or anything else

Be thankful and glad you got to meet, sharing a small amount of time together

Laugh, smile, be kind to everyone around you and it’ll make our day better
postsData.commentAdded: Your perspective is truly inspiring! Celebrating each moment reminds us to cherish connections and uplift one another. Thank you for sharing! 🌟

postsData.content:
Customer Success is one of the BEST careers out there. 

It’s not just a job; it’s a launchpad for whatever you want to do next in your career.

Imagine being in a role where you:

 Gain deep insights into multiple business models
 Work directly with leaders and founders
 Develop a systems-thinking mindset
 Master cross-functional execution
 Lead transformative change

That’s exactly what you develop as a CSM.

Customer Success isn’t just about keeping customers happy—it’s about building a career foundation that gives you the experience and skills to thrive anywhere.

But here’s the trick: You need to see your role this way.

It's not enough to just clock in, clock out, and go through the motions. Half-assing your way through the day will only get you so far.

To maximise the value of this role, you have to show up with the right mindset and behaviours. Here’s how:

1️⃣ Curiosity:
You’ll be exposed to a variety of business challenges. Don’t just solve problems—ask questions. Dive deep and understand the why behind every decision. Curiosity unlocks new opportunities for growth—for both your customers and your career. The more you learn, the further you can go.

2️⃣ Be Proactive:
Waiting for customers to reach out? That's not enough. The magic happens when you anticipate their needs and take the lead in solving problems before they arise. Being proactive not only builds your reputation as a leader, but it also strengthens your relationships and positions you as someone who adds REAL value.

3️⃣ Collaborate Often:
You’ll work with a variety of teams—Sales, Marketing, Product, and more. Communication is essential, but alignment is everything. Learn how each department works, what success looks like for them, and use that knowledge to deliver better results. Mastering collaboration now will set you up for success in ANY future role, no matter where you go.

By adopting these behaviours, you’ll maximize your impact, accelerate your learning, and unlock endless opportunities—turning Customer Success into more than just a job but a career foundation that sets you up for whatever comes next.

Ready to unlock the full potential of Customer Success?

 Join 14.5K professionals and sign up to Unconventional Growth [link in the comments].

What NFL Athletes Can Teach Us About Leadership 

In the run-up to the Super Bowl last night, I was reflecting on what leaders can learn from professional athletes to become more effective. Three things came to mind:

 Master the Fundamentals: Just as great players excel at blocking and tackling, great leaders thrive on solid fundamentals—business acumen, industry knowledge, and leadership skills. The secret? Deliberate practice and continuous learning.

 Cultivate Agility: The best athletes, like Peyton Manning, adapt in real time. Likewise, agile leaders embrace change, think critically, and anticipate what’s around the corner.

 Obsess Over Focus: Winning isn’t about the scoreboard—it’s about consistent execution. Leaders who focus on daily excellence, not just long-term goals, build lasting success.

Ready to elevate your leadership game? Check out my latest article, and better yet, let's connect and learn how we atcan help take you and your team to the next level.

postsData.content:
𝐀𝐈 𝐀𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬: 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐍𝐞𝐱𝐭 𝐁𝐢𝐠 𝐒𝐡𝐢𝐟𝐭 𝐢𝐧 𝐒𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐀𝐮𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 

AI agents are changing the way we interact with technology. These smart systems can analyze data, make decisions, and take action—all with minimal human input. But how do they actually function, and what makes them so impactful?

𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐀𝐈 𝐀𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐖𝐨𝐫𝐤?
- AI agents observe their environment, store important information, and perform tasks based on specific goals. They can work independently or under human supervision, ensuring a balance between automation and control.

𝐊𝐞𝐲 𝐂𝐚𝐩𝐚𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐞𝐬:
 Autonomy – They can act on their own or follow user instructions.
 Memory & Learning – They remember past interactions, learn preferences, and improve over time.
 Environmental Awareness – They process real-time data to make smart decisions.
 Tool Integration – They connect with the internet, APIs, and other systems.
 Collaboration – They work with humans or other AI agents for seamless execution.

𝐓𝐲𝐩𝐞𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐀𝐈 𝐀𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬:
AI agents come in various forms, from basic task automation to advanced decision-making systems:
 Single Agents – AI-powered personal assistants managing tasks.
 Multi-Agent Systems – Groups of AI agents working together for complex problem-solving.
 Human-Machine Teams – AI enhancing human decision-making in critical areas.

𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐥-𝐓𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐔𝐬𝐞 𝐂𝐚𝐬𝐞
AI in Healthcare Support: An AI agent assists doctors by analyzing patient symptoms and suggesting potential diagnoses. If unsure, it escalates the case to a specialist with a summary of key details, ensuring faster and more accurate treatment.

AI agents are already making a difference across industries. How do you see them shaping the future of work? Let’s discuss in the comments!

Natalia Cano

postsData.content:
'Sorry' is one of the most overused words.

Over-justifying actions often follows.

Doing more harm than good:

 Undermines your message
 Shifts focus from the issue
 Diminishes your authority
 Sound insincere

15 Ways to Apologise

(without using ‘sorry’).

1. How can I make this right?
↳ Demonstrates your proactive approach

2. What can I do to fix this?
↳ Shows your commitment to finding a solution

3. I appreciate your patience
↳ Expresses gratitude for their willingness to work it out

4. I understand I made a mistake
↳ Acknowledges your error without making excuses

5. I can see why you feel that way
↳ Validates their perspective

6. I didn't mean for that to happen
↳ Focuses on intent, but don't use as an excuse

7. I'll make sure it doesn't happen again
↳ Offers reassurance about future behavior

8. I'm disappointed in how I handled this
↳ Shows genuine remorse and self-reflection

9. That wasn't my intention. Let me clarify
↳ Good for misunderstandings, be genuine

10. I was wrong, and I want to make it right
↳ Simple, direct, and sincere

11. I take full responsibility for my actions
↳ Emphasizes your willingness to own the situation

12. Thank you for bringing this to my attention
↳ Shows appreciation for the feedback

13. I appreciate you telling me. It helps me learn
↳ Shows a growth mindset

14. I understand how this must have affected you
↳ Acknowledges the other person's feelings

15. How can we avoid this happening again?
↳ Focuses on solutions and partnership

Which one will you use next time?

Let me know in the comments 

‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾
️ Repost this to help others
 Followfor daily content like this

Bezos & Musk use this in every product
Nobel Laureate Daniel Kahneman showed them how

5 Product Psychology Principles:

1/ The Priming Effect
↳ Netflix suggests relevant categories
↳ Spotify creates personalized playlists
↳ 58%+ engagement when content matches intent
[Source: Statista, 2024]

2/ Dopamine Done Right
↳ Duolingo's streak rewards
↳ Strava's achievement badges
↳ 2.4x higher user retention
[Source: MixBloom, 2024]

3/ Friction-Free Experience
↳ Apple Pay's seamless checkout
↳ Google Maps' smart suggestions
↳ 28.5% increase in user satisfaction
[Source:, 2024]

4/ Progress & Achievement
↳ LinkedIn profile completion bar
↳ Headspace's journey tracking
↳ 40% higher goal completion
[Source: Nature, 2024]

5/ Social Connection
↳ Strava's community challenges
↳ Figma's collaborative features
↳ 3x higher user engagement
[Source: Sybill AI, 2024]

Key Design Ethics:
↳ Always add user value
↳ Respect user time
↳ Create genuine delight
↳ Build trust through transparency
